article_title: What’s on the China agenda today
article_text:
What’s on the China agenda today

With help from Joseph Marks, David Perera and Adam Sneed

BUT HOW WAS THE FISH MARKET, MR. XI? — Chinese President Xi Jinping touches down in Seattle today and will give an address this evening at a dinner hosted by the US-China Business Council and the National Committee on U.S.-China Relations beginning at 7 p.m. (4 p.m. local time). Check out the livestream here: http://bit.ly/1KvGksG Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker will also be in attendance at the forum this week as President Barack Obama’s representative, the AP reports. http://bit.ly/1OMgzcJ

Story Continued Below

While economic hacking promises to be a major topic once Xi reaches Washington, sidebar conversations in Seattle are just as likely to focus on a proposed Chinese banking law. An earlier draft of that law drew widespread condemnation from industry and governments in the U.S., Europe and Japan for demanding companies in the sector turn over source code to Chinese officials. A coalition of industry organizations, including the US-China Business Council, penned a letter earlier this month urging the Chinese government not to demand companies' source code and to adhere to global standards on encryption. Background: http://politico.pro/1FeeFPX

RICE SEEMS TO SOFTEN LANGUAGE ON CHINESE HACKING — National Security Adviser Susan Rice on Monday threatened less dire consequences if Chinese economic hacking continues than Obama did previously in a speech previewing the Xi visit. Rice noted only that the U.S. will “continue to urge China to join us in promoting responsible norms of state behavior in cyberspace," and that continued hacking would be “a critical factor in determining the future trajectory of U.S.-China ties.” Obama had previously warned that the U.S. was “prepared to take some countervailing action” on cybertheft, a likely reference to targeted sanctions. http://politico.pro/1MmnZ44

THE IMPORTANCE OF TALKING TO CYBER FRENEMIES — Rice also used her address to respond to critics who said the U.S. should cancel Xi’s visit over the hacks at U.S. companies and the Office of Personnel Management. Engagement with China helped produce deals on trade and climate change, Rice said. She warned that shunning engagement would “only ensure the Chinese are not challenged on issues where we differ and not encouraged to peacefully rise.” Chief among those critics was Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, who suspended his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination just hours after Rice’s address. http://politico.pro/1OqFF1F

HAPPY TUESDAY and welcome to Morning Cybersecurity. Your regular MC concierge has returned from Colorado and his best friend’s wedding (go Jim and Rebecca!). Though I miss the mountains and my old pals already, I’m back and eager to serve. Send your thoughts, feedback and especially your tips to tstarks@politico.com and follow @timstarks, @POLITICOPro and @MorningCybersec. Full team info is below.

FIRST LOOK: FEDS THE SECOND-SAFEST SECTOR ON CYBER? — The federal government is just behind the finance sector in its cybersecurity performance, according to security ratings firm BitSight Technologies, which is out with its annual industry benchmark report today. Given all the attention over the big breaches at OPM, IRS and Joint Chiefs of Staff this year, that’s a bit of a surprise. But BitSight said it surveyed 119 government agencies and found a slight improvement from last year.

Other takeaways: BitSight ranks the education sector the worst of the six industries it examined by a good margin, with the energy/utility and health care sectors in the back half of the pack. Retail tracks fairly even with the federal government. Finance’s supremacy, and education’s poor performance, are trends that BitSight has observed in the past. And every industry has major SSL vulnerabilities, according to BitSight. The full report: http://bit.ly/1LIWleG

TODAY: HACKERONE DEBUTS MODEL TO MEASURE HACKER FRIENDLINESS — Bug bounty platform provider HackerOne unveils today a first-ever maturity model for companies to measure their ability to accept, and act on, findings of outside researchers who discover security flaws. “No software is immune to bugs; for most organizations it’s not a matter of if they’ll have an external hacker reporting security vulnerabilities, but when,” said Katie Moussouris, chief policy officer. The National Telecommunications and Information Administration holds on Sept. 29 the first in a series of public meetings dedicated to the issue in Berkeley, Calif. – where Moussouris says the maturity model will be discussed. The model rates companies according to five capabilities: Organizational, Incentives, Analytics, Communications and Engineering. It then rates them across three levels of ability: Basic, Advanced and Expert. More from HackerOne: http://bit.ly/1V6K6xy

SCOOPLET: COMMERCE LOOKING TO REVISE CYBERSECURITY FRAMEWORK — The National Institute of Standards and Technology Cybersecurity Framework was a signature Obama administration cybersecurity initiative, and the framework’s voluntary industry guidance is nearing its third birthday. “We think people are ready to come back to the table and talk about their experiences and think about what needs to be updated,” Adam Sedgewick, a senior information technology policy adviser for NIST, told Dave. On Sedgewick’s list: updated cybersecurity controls referenced in the framework, and how to use risk management frameworks together with the guidance. For Pros: http://politico.pro/1Krl4q1

** A message from Northrop Grumman: Today’s enemy threats have taken on forms like never before. That’s why our full-spectrum cyber capabilities enable our military to tackle challenges at the push of a button. See how at http://bit.ly/1IM0OAJ **

ZERO-DAY BONANZA FOR APPLE IOS 9 HACKERS — A broker of unpatched vulnerabilities known as zero-days is offering hackers $1 million for the exclusive rights to an exploitable vulnerability in Apple’s new iOS 9 system. Zerodium, founded by notorious zero day supplier Chaouki Bekrar, says it’ll pay out if a hacker shows how to permanently jailbreak the latest Apple mobile operating system via code embedded into a website. The dollar amount and the publicity surrounding the offer are unusual – the zero-day market is dominated by stealth and secrecy, especially given heavy participation of intelligence agencies. Governments usually shell out $300,000 to $400,000 per zero day, said Robert Graham, who heads up Errata Security. (Graham doesn’t discuss whether he sells zero days.)

The $1 million price looks high, but it involves levels of technical sophistication that could be sold individually for about $300,000 each, he said. Graham predicted a government would be the party most interested in buying the jailbreak zero days, since that would give it the ability to remotely take over a target’s cellphone.

It’s also another illustration of the obstacles cyber defenders face when trying to patch zero days before the offensive side (as Zerodium likely sells to) of cybersecurity can make use of them, said Moussouris of HackerOne. “More defense-oriented incentives are needed, though they will never be able to compete with these prices, so using other levers besides price will have to be part of any defender's strategy,” she said. More from Zerodium: http://bit.ly/1isXbVy

CYBER DIPLOMACY HITS MAPUTO — State Department officials will be in Maputo, Mozambique, today through Thursday for a workshop on cybersecurity and cybercrime, according to a State Department notice. State Department Cyber Coordinator Chris Painter’s office has held at least one cyber conference in Africa each year since the office was created in 2011, part of an effort to build cybersecurity along with cyber capacity in the developing world. “This workshop will address broad issues of cybercrime and cybersecurity while focusing on issues of specific interest to the Lusophone Africa region such as combating cybercrime; mobile phone security; Internet freedom, access, and affordability; and the development of national computer emergency readiness teams,” according to the notice. More from State: http://1.usa.gov/1QUOgbg

CDM ORDERS AWARDED — The Department of Homeland Security announced Monday that after three more task orders, 97 percent of federal government agencies now have access to DHS’s Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation program tools and services. The remaining 3 percent is due to be covered by the end of the year. Booz Allen Hamilton, Northrop Grumman and HP Enterprise Services won the orders. More for Pros: http://politico.pro/1OqC43A

After we published, we got the names of the 17 agencies covered under the new batch of orders. Those are: Commerce; Education; Environmental Protection Agency; General Services Administration; Health and Human Services; Housing and Urban Development; Justice; Labor; National Aeronautics and Space Administration; National Science Foundation; Nuclear Regulatory Commission; Social Security Administration; Small Business Administration; State; Treasury; U.S. Agency for International Development; and U.S. Postal Service. Past orders, via Federal Times: http://bit.ly/1Fq3zay

SENATE DROPS INTEL BILL’S SOCIAL MEDIA PROVISION — From our friends at Morning Technology: Internet companies are cheering changes to the Senate’s intelligence reauthorization bill that would have required social media services to report suspected terrorist activity to authorities. Senate leaders abandoned that requirement on Monday, causing Sen. Ron Wyden to lift his hold on the bill. Internet Association spokesman Noah Theran called it an encouraging development. “Requiring Internet companies to provide law enforcement enormous quantities of data does not make us safer, and stands in stark conflict with long-standing federal policy governing platform liability and free speech online," he said in a statement.

QUICK BYTES

— A confidential Verizon report on the 2013 Target hack determined that Verizon’s consultants could even hack into deli meat scales, but that Target had improved by early 2014. Krebs on Security: http://bit.ly/1NOlQRG

— India is getting aggressive on encrypted products. The Register: http://bit.ly/1QuBY8P

— There was an authorization gap between the kind of phone and email metadata President George W. Bush wanted to collect and what it was actually collecting. New York Times: http://nyti.ms/1FaG0md

— One of the country’s largest sheriff’s departments was quite enthusiastic about using Hacking Team tools. Motherboard: http://bit.ly/1MFwtGe

— The malware-infected apps from Apple’s App Store were the result of developers in China being “tricked into using software tools that added malicious code,” according to the AP. http://cbsn.ws/1NH9V6B

— The IRS has stepped up its efforts to block fraudulent tax refunds earlier in the process. The Hill: http://bit.ly/1KrJobr

That’s all for today. Apparently while I was out … http://bit.ly/1fk55I0

Stay in touch with the whole team: Joseph Marks (JMarks@politico.com, @Joseph_Marks_); David Perera (dperera@politico.com, @daveperera); and Tim Starks (tstarks@politico.com, @timstarks).
